option.value: Leveraging AI in Learning and Development

slidelink.displaytext: What is AI? What does it look like in L&D?
Benefits and Risks of AI in Corporate Training
Question 01: Which of the following is an example of a risk associated with using AI in L&D?
Question 02: Drag and drop the benefits and risks of AI in corporate training—listed at the bottom of the screen—to the proper column.

Question 03: Scenario – You’re part of the L&D team at a growing organization. You’re exploring AI tools to solve common training challenges. Below are three situations your team is facing. Match each one to the AI tool that best addresses the need.
Question 04: Scenario – You’re rolling out an adaptive onboarding path for roles across different departments. Select the best option.
Question 05: Scenario – You need to keep compliance content up to date across departments. Select the best option.
You're Ready to Lead the Future of Learning

search.slidetext: hover over each image to learn more. machine learning neural networks digital assistants what is ai? what does it look like in l&d?

scenario no. 3 return return return return return return i am stuck on a policy training module. i click a chatbot icon and type, “what is the dress code policy?” instantly, the chatbot responds with a summary and link to the hr handbook. what kind of ai am i interacting with? it’s a digital assistant. digital assistants—like chatbots—are designed to answer questions and provide real-time learner support. scenario no. 2 return return return return return return i am completing a compliance course that automatically adapts based on my quiz scores. when i struggle with a concept, the course offers remedial material. when i excel, it skips ahead. which ai-powered system is enabling this adaptive behavior? it’s a neural network. neural networks are often used in adaptive systems to detect performance patterns and adjust content accordingly. scenario no. 1 i manage onboarding for a fast-growing tech company. over time, i notice that the lms starts recommending different training resources to new hires based on their roles and performance in earlier modules. what kind of ai is likely driving this personalized learning experience? it’s machine learning. machine learning models analyze past data to improve recommendations over time. return return return return return return select each image below to explore real-world scenarios. ai scenarios

ai in l&d isn’t just a future concept—it’s already here, transforming how we train, support, and engage learners every day. let’s review three real-world applications you’re likely to encounter. hover over each to learn more. real-world applications
hover over each image. use <back> and <forward> to navigate. back back back back back back forward forward forward forward forward forward benefits and risks of ai in corporate training
knowledge check you’ve explored the benefits, risks, and real-world applications of ai in l&d. now it’s time to test what you’ve learned.

terms.term: AI-powered systems analyze learner performance in real time and adjust the learning path accordingly. Struggling learners receive additional practice, while high performers can skip ahead—creating a more efficient and personalized experience.

A risk of AI in L&D. AI learns from data—and if that data reflects bias (intentional or not), the system may perpetuate it. For example, recommendation engines might favor certain learner profiles while excluding others, leading to inequities in training opportunities.
Artificial Intelligence (AI) refers to machines that can simulate human intelligence—learning from data, making decisions, and solving problems.

A benefit of AI in L&D. AI can handle repetitive L&D tasks like grading assessments, sending reminders, or curating content. This frees up instructional designers and trainers to focus on strategic and creative work.

These virtual assistants provide instant support to learners—answering questions, directing them to resources, and even coaching them through content. They’re available 24/7 and help reduce the burden on help desks and facilitators.

AI scans large volumes of content to find, organize, and recommend the most relevant materials based on a learner’s role, goals, or interests. This saves time and ensures that learners get the right content at the right time.

A benefit of AI in L&D. AI systems track learner progress and interactions continuously. These insights help L&D teams make data-informed decisions—such as identifying struggling learners early or refining content that’s underperforming.

A risk of AI in L&D. AI tools often require access to large amounts of personal learner data. Without strict safeguards, this can lead to privacy violations, regulatory non-compliance, or misuse of sensitive information.
Chatbots or voice-based tools that answer questions, provide guidance, and support learners 24/7.

A strategic function within organizations focused on improving employee performance, capability, and growth through training, education, and skill-building initiatives. It aims to align workforce development with business goals by equipping employees with the knowledge, tools, and competencies needed to succeed in their roles—both now and in the future.
These algorithms learn from patterns in data to make predictions or decisions without being explicitly programmed. In L&D, they help personalize content delivery.
Inspired by the human brain, these are used in deep learning to recognize complex patterns—useful for adaptive learning paths.

A risk of AI in L&D. Depending too heavily on AI can lead to reduced human oversight and less meaningful trainer-learner interaction. It may also cause organizations to overlook the emotional or contextual factors that influence learning.

A benefit of AI in L&D. AI can tailor content, pace, and delivery style to each learner's needs. By analyzing performance data, preferences, and behavior, AI creates individualized learning paths—improving engagement, retention, and outcomes.
